biography.value:
Born from the convergence of a potent magical leyline and a pristine, ancient spring deep within the earth, the Aqueous Arcanist is more than just an elemental; it is a living repository of arcane knowledge. Unlike its more primal kin, it possesses a keen intellect and an insatiable curiosity for magic. It has spent centuries observing, learning, and absorbing the ambient magical energies of its secluded grotto, refining its innate water-based abilities into sophisticated spellcraft. It views itself as a guardian of its sacred pool and the magical secrets it holds, often interacting with intruders first through warnings and illusions before unleashing its formidable power. It might appear aloof or even dismissive, but deep down, it seeks to understand the world's magic, sometimes offering cryptic guidance or ancient lore in exchange for new magical insights.

Behavior: The Aqueous Arcanist is a highly intelligent combatant, prioritizing control and area denial with spells like *sleet storm* and *fog cloud*, while using *misty step* for tactical repositioning. It saves its potent *lightning bolt* or *tidal wave* for clustered enemies or high-threat targets. It will use *Hydro-Kinetic Surge* to maximize the impact of its *Torrent Blast* or a key spell against a priority foe. It prefers to keep distance, using its movement and elemental nature to avoid melee.

Appearance: A sphere of perfectly clear water, roughly the size of a human's fist, constantly shifting and rippling as if containing a miniature storm. Within its depths, a faint, pulsing blue light emanates, hinting at the vast arcane energy it wields. Occasionally, tiny, ephemeral eyes or a mouth might briefly form and dissipate on its surface.

Twist: Hydro-Kinetic Surge: As a bonus action, the Arcanist can empower its next spell or Torrent Blast cast before the end of its next turn. The damage of that spell or Torrent Blast increases by 2d6, or its spell save DC increases by 1 (player's choice).

Habitat: Ancient magical springs or secluded grottoes, often hidden deep within old-growth forests or forgotten ruins.

Treasure: Standard, often carries a small, smooth river stone that glows faintly with absorbed arcane energy (a minor magical focus or component).

description.value: the [[lookup @name lowercase]]Â can move through a space as narrow as 1 inch wide without squeezing.

The [[lookup @details.type.config.label lowercase]]'s innate spellcasting ability is Charisma. It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

At will: detect magic, fog cloud, light

3/day each: feather fall, fly, misty step, telekinesis

1/day each: control weather, gaseous form

A frigid beam of blue-white light streaks toward a creature within range. Make a ranged spell attack against the target. On a hit, it takes 1d8 cold damage, and its speed is reduced by 10 feet until the start of your next turn.

The spell's damage increases by 1d8 when you reach 5th level (2d8), 11th level (3d8), and 17th level (4d8).

You create a 20-foot-radius Sphere of fog centered on a point within range. The sphere spreads around corners, and its area is heavily obscured. It lasts for the Duration or until a wind of moderate or greater speed (at least 10 miles per hour) disperses it.

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, the radius of the fog increases by 20 feet for each slot level above 1st.

A sudden loud ringing noise, painfully intense, erupts from a point of your choice within range. Each creature in a 10-foot-radius sphere centered on that point must make a Constitution saving throw. A creature takes 3d8 thunder damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. A creature made of inorganic material such as stone, crystal, or metal has disadvantage on this saving throw.

A nonmagical object that isn't being worn or carried also takes the damage if it's in the spell's area.

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a 3 or higher level spell slot, the damage of the spell increases by 1d8 for each level of higher spell slot 2.
Briefly surrounded by silvery mist, you teleport up to 30 feet to an unoccupied space that you can see.

A line of strong wind 60 feet long and 10 feet wide blasts from you in a direction you choose for the spell's duration. Each creature that starts its turn in the line must succeed on a Strength saving throw or be pushed 15 feet away from you in a direction following the line.

Any creature in the line must spend 2 feet of movement for every 1 foot it moves when moving closer to you.

The gust disperses gas or vapor, and it extinguishes candles, torches, and similar unprotected flames in the area. It causes protected flames, such as those of lanterns, to dance wildly and has a 50 percent chance to extinguish them.

As a bonus action on each of your turns before the spell ends, you can change the direction in which the line blasts from you.

A stroke of lightning forming a line 100 feet long and 5 feet wide blasts out from you in a direction you choose. Each creature in the line must make a Dexterity saving throw. A creature takes 8d6 lightning damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

The lightning ignites flammable objects in the area that aren't being worn or carried.

At Higher Levels. When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, the damage increases by 1d6 for each slot level above 3rd.

materials.value: A bit of fur and a rod of amber, crystal, or glass

description.value:
Until the spell ends, freezing rain and sleet fall in a 20-foot-tall cylinder with a 40-foot radius centered on a point you choose within range. The area is heavily obscured, and exposed flames in the area are doused.

The ground in the area is covered with slick ice, making it difficult terrain. When a creature enters the spell's area for the first time on a turn or starts its turn there, it must make a Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, it falls Prone.

If a creature is concentrating in the spell's area, the creature must make a successful Constitution saving throw against your spell save DC or lose concentration.

materials.value: A pinch of dust and a few drops of water.

description.value: The arcanist can enter a hostile creature's space and stop there. It can move through any nonmagical opening without impediment.
You can move and manipulate water. This cantrip is common for water-based creatures, allowing them to instantly change the form of a 5-foot cube of water within range.

A wave of water crashes down in a 30-foot cube within range. Each creature in that area must make a Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, a creature takes 4d8 bludgeoning damage and is knocked prone. On a successful save, a creature takes half as much damage and isn't knocked prone.
